Supposing that we have the mapping $\phi: H \rightarrow H$ (where $H$ is
the upper half plane), then the mapping
$\mu : {\mathbb{R}} \rightarrow {\mathbb{R}}$, such that
$\mu(x) = \phi(x)$ where $x \in {\mathbb{R}}$, is the boundary
correspondence of $\phi$.

To prove the sufficiency of the above theorem Beurling and Ahlfors
[@ba1956] define $\phi$ as follows. Given a $\mu$ that is a
quasisymmetric mapping of the real line onto itself and fixes $\infty$,
we define a map $\phi(x,y) = u(x,y) + iu(x,y)$ where $$\begin{aligned}
u(x,y) & = \frac{1}{2y} \int_{-y}^y \mu(x+t) dt ,
\\
v(x,y) & = \frac{1}{2y} \int_0^y (\mu(x+t) - \mu(x-t)) dt .\end{aligned}$$

Intuitively $\phi$ is a function which “smoothes” out any kinks in the
function $\mu$ as we get further and further away from the real line. It
therefore intuitively follows that $\phi$ has the worst (highest)
dilatation near the $x$ axis, which actually turns out to be true.
